On 8 May, thousands of Moroccans marched in Marrakesh to demand reforms and express their opposition towards terrorist attacks, like the one on 28 April.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thousands demand reform in Morocco rally |author=Souhail Karam |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE74716020110508?sp=true |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=8 May 2011 |accessdate=11 May 2011}}</ref>
On 8 May, thousands of Moroccans marched in Marrakesh to demand reforms and express their opposition towards terrorist attacks, like the one on 28 April.<ref>{{cite news |title=Thousands demand reform in Morocco rally |author=Souhail Karam |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/topNews/idCATRE74716020110508?sp=true |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |date=8 May 2011 |accessdate=11 May 2011}}</ref>

{{wikinews|Unrest spreads to Morocco; police violently break up demonstrations}}
 
On 22 May, Moroccan police spent hours chasing hundreds of pro-democracy activists through the streets of the capital in an effort to prevent any pro-reform demonstrations.
On 22 May, Moroccan police spent hours chasing hundreds of pro-democracy activists through the streets of the capital in an effort to prevent any pro-reform demonstrations.
The government appeared to be implementing a new zero tolerance policy for protesters. <ref>[http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/Article_2011-05-22-ML-Morocco-Demonstrations/id-paaa0869d0d074b9388450639c6688ea5 Associated Press 22 May 2011]</ref>
The government appeared to be implementing a new zero tolerance policy for protesters. <ref>[http://hosted2.ap.org/APDEFAULT/Article_2011-05-22-ML-Morocco-Demonstrations/id-paaa0869d0d074b9388450639c6688ea5 Associated Press 22 May 2011]</ref>
